they're different now say friends and

to see I'm Jody Kanter for the New York
Times the Obamas have become better
politicians more adapt but also more
conventional when they work a room now
people say they seem looser less weary
less tense they linger in ways they
never used two years ago Michelle Obama
told an old boss that the only thing she
liked about campaigning was picking up

rooms this year she threw herself into

initiative to encourage people to vote
it takes one and it starts with you
unlike many first couples the Obamas
once staked themselves on the idea of
doing things differently on not being
regular politicians in the past they
could appear to be critical observers of
politics so above it all that they were
sometimes reluctant to participate these
days the president seems to show more

while we seemed to know what the
president wants from his second term the
real question in some ways is the first
lady so far she stuck to a very safe
strategy working on important issues
like childhood obesity but interpreting
her role very traditionally but Michelle
Obama has changed and grown those close
to her say becoming more experienced and
confident so how will she use those
qualities finally when you watch Barack
Obama at this inauguration remember that
he has become a full-time crisis manager
a man who sees death and human suffering
all the time when he travelled to
Newtown Connecticut last month he met
with each family hearing their stories
looking at the photos of their children
crying with the families and then giving
a major speech in public at which he
cried again whatever portion of sadness
that we can share with you to ease this
heavy load we will gladly bear in fact
he's been crying a lot more in public
lately for example when he thanked
campaign aides the day after the
election that's a change for a president
known for his poker face and perhaps a
clue to just how deeply the job of
president has affected and changed
